author: fhilip.k
title: Authentication Protocol Work Group
description: Projects are working on Authentication solutions in isolation. Communication between these solutions is required.

f6_assessments.q0: As a reader, I personally feel there are a lot of areas the proposal is lacking in. I agree that we as a community might need a unified standard authentication protocol and mechanism going ahead, but I wouldn't agree with the approach the proposer tries here. The main challenge, as the proposer himself mentions is making sure the existing application teams reserve a part of themselves to be in the workgroup which decides and formulates the protocol agreed upon. That would be a tough one to tackle. And many have found their comfort in their own authentication mechanisms ready and asking them all to switch is not gonna be an easy task. Even though the idea is fresh and springy, the proposer needs to provide more research or do more spadework before going ahead and implementing this idea. The challenges are plenty and the approach is fuzzy with a lot of dependency on other projects making it look weak.
f6_assessments.q1: The detailed plan is kept very simple and to the point. The proposer mentions the two phases that will make up the entire proposal. Most of the work here is done by the participants who are a part of other teams already working on projects with far superior goals. The feasibility of getting them on board is something to be concerned about. The few roles such as administrator, maintainers are defined with clear roles but there are no names mentioned who might be filling these shoes and hence making the integrity and credibility of the proposal take a hit. The fund requested do not feel justified after taking a closer look at the breakdown. There are several projects in the same proposal asking for much less and doing much more (P.S: It's a personal opinion), and it looks like a lot of roles have been overemphasized and the retainer for those roles seems a little overestimated with no idea about the kind of experienced people who might be taking up those roles. Hence, I am in a fix regarding the feasibility of the proposal.
f6_assessments.q2: With most part of the proposal being meetings and communication of the minutes of meetings to the community, there is not much to track in the proposal. Moreover, the implementation of the agreed-upon protocol will not be undertaken but will instead be encouraged to be taken up by future application developers. To be honest, I don't see the necessity of a workgroup for this. A group of enthusiastic developers who are willing to work on something of the sort could all make use of some community hub and come to a conclusion. However, the only positive outcome would be the formal documentation of the meetings which might not happen in the other case. And the success outcome defined by the proposer is somewhat the same. The team also makes a mention about the need for funds to maintain the protocol which they probably won't be developing themselves. I find it hard to assess the exact implementation and the success of this proposal and I personally feel the community should be cautious provided they fund the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: Interoperability is one of the key ideas of Cardano. We know that this is important for supporting decentralization and even scalability in the Cardano ecosystem. I like this idea of creating these work groups because it will help community members to come together and learn more. I would like to learn more about what these work groups would be focused on. However, I enjoy reading through these different ideas. I like that this proposal gives a clear statement on their potential risks/challenges with this proposal. It may be hard to find the dedicated members that will be willing to bring these parties together, but if done correctly, this idea will promote the idea of interoperability and help educate newer users on why that is important in Cardano. For these reasons, I give this section of the proposal a 4 out of 5 stars.
f6_assessments.q1: I would love to read more about the team members in this proposal. I like that there is a list of the different positions needed to carry-out this proposal. However, I think that it would also be very important to give names of those that will be working in these areas and the experience that each member has. This will help the voters to follow-up on this proposal and to help the team stay accountable. If this information is included, I could give a higher rating. For right now, I give this section of the proposal a 3 out of 5 stars for the reasons given.
f6_assessments.q2: There were 2 parts of this proposal that I think were very informative. The first part that caught my attention was the roadmap given. This roadmap gives a detailed explanation on what the team is going to achieve with the potential funds given. The 2nd thing that helped me identify if this proposal has enough information to be successful is the detailed report of the budget breakdown. It is clearly explained where the funds are going to be used. This also helps the community to keep the team accountable to be successful with their proposal if funded. For these reasons, I give this section of the proposal a 4 out of 5 stars.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposer rightfully states that projects working on authentication solutions are doing this in isolation, and that a communication solution is required. Of course, this is in general a valid statement, however it does not shed light on a very specific topic and is rather broad in my opinion. The proposed solution is to organize 6 meetings to be held, but it is not very clear between whom, and at the end the meetings a protocol would emerge, but it is not clear for what purpose other than “authentication”. The overall vagueness leaves a lot to be desired and there is no clear way to link the proposal to the challenge. I propose that future iterations specify more clearly at least the target audience of the meetings and what outcomes they would have.
f6_assessments.q1:
There are very vague descriptions of “roles” to participate in the project, like for instance facilitator, organizer, treasurer, maintainers. For future iterations I highly recommend that at least the core team behind the projects comes out to light with names and even Linkedin profiles available. 

In terms of budget there are many questions to be asked and the logic behind it is not very clear. For instance, participant fees are an important part - will they be industry experts, general audience, or whom exactly? It is not clear at all. Every other budget caption is also vague and / or out of logic - i shall spare you the details here. I highly advise that future iterations make a much more clear budget, perhaps employ some outside help in order to structure the information better. 

Timewise, the project would take 6 months. In the first month we would have built the coalition of participants, drafting the process and research of participants. The next months would see the meetings taking place, closing meetings and a closing meeting. Again a very clear lack of structure in the timeline. 

In a nutshell, poor feasibility across the board.
f6_assessments.q2: The team promises that the minutes and recordings of the 6 meetings and the protocol would be released and provided to the community. Not many holes to punch in the promises made here, but given the poor feasibility and problem definition, I take with a grain of salt absolutely every promise made in terms of delivering the project and communicating publicly. Four stars just in order to judge the auditability independently of all other criteria.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal is almost identical* with the Ideation Protocol Work Group proposal (https://cardano.ideascale.com/c/idea/400140) but I find this one more relevant.

The challenge is to "build an open ecosystem to drive growth, give equal opportunities to all, and increase the synergies across Cardano projects". This structured and incentivized approach is well thought out and it will make it easy for any authentication-related project to follow. Although a bit pricey, this can, on the other hand, cut costs down the line when others don't have to figure out what standards to follow. It is also very important that authentication solutions are mutually interoperable. The results of this working group should help in that, too.

(*Dear VCAs and similarity-assessing bots, I have utilized some of the same wordings in both of my assessments because the proposals really are almost identical).
f6_assessments.q1: Philip is an upstanding community member without whom the Catalyst process would have been more cumbersome and less effective. He has built AIM tools that we all use and he has participated in improvement and documentation of the process itself. Should this proposal get funded, we can rest assured it will get done. There are two points that I would like to see improved, however. First, I would have enjoyed seeing at least some inclination what those participating projects could be, to understand whether the formation is starting from the scratch or if efforts have been taken to get things going already. Second, when discussing the risks, I have a feeling Philip didn't dig deep enough. Rather than just saying "people might not come", it's important to ask "why they wouldn't come". Regardless, a solid proposal with a reasonable budget.
f6_assessments.q2: Auditability has been well outlined and it is clear that there will be a high degree of transparency into the process, as well as open sharing of the results. The deliverables, the step-by-step process, the timeline and required roles make sense. There is one thing that could have been improved, however. That is the fact that measures were missing. Moreover, if not the partipants yet, it would have been good to have the maintainers, treasurer, administrator, organizer and facilitator named. Now we can just assume that as sole proposer it's Philip who wears all those hats.

f6_assessments.q0:
The problem being projects which are working on Authentication solutions are working in isolation. The Communication between them is needed. The proposer is trying to resolve it by conducting series of summits with projects which are already working on Authentication 
 solutions and make them agree on protocol level implementations. The given solution does address the problem which is needed to be solved. By doing this efficiency on the development of Authentication solutions will improve and will help speed up the development of Authentication solutions hence adding value to the cardano ecosystem. The metrics and goals of the proposal do align with the challenge. This proposal can be improvised to increase the communication between projects working on same idea in future to meet the future challenges. Based on these observation it can be said the proposal effectively addresses the problem
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer himself has been working in the catalyst process and have previously worked on many projects related to cardano. The proposer has mentioned the roles that would be required for the proposal and also explained the duty of each roles. By taking all these into account it can said that the proposer has the required skill and experience to make this proposal a reality. The proposal consist of a clear budget breakdown which will be very helpful to understand the requirement of the funds. The budget requested also looks practical and reasonable. The detailed timeline given seems reasonable to complete the proposal.
The proposer has taken into all the resources that may be required to carry out the proposal and have mentioned all the possible risks and challenges that would affect the execution of the proposal. However these challenges are out of proposer hand and it depends on the projects but it's good to know that the proposer will put their effort to make sure the parties work together. By taking all these above into account it's safe to say that it is highly likely this proposal will be implemented successfully
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal makes no mistakes when giving the metrics the auditors can use these to track the progress. The clear success definition and roadmap with milestones will help increase confidence among the community regarding the proposal's successfully implementation. The timeline provided in the proposal will be very helpful for auditors to know whether the development of proposal is as per the plan or is it lagging behind. The proposal do consist of a clear explanation of addressed problem and also has effectively solution that targets the problem. The proposer has also provided a clear budget breakdown which come in handy while auditing. With all these info is it can said the given information should be enough to track the progress of the proposal and also to audit the success of the proposal
